title: 110_hr6784
content: The "Home Heating Oil Assistance Act of 2008" provides a refundable credit for residential energy costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Home Heating Oil Assistance Act of 2008" offers a tax credit for residential energy costs based on a percentage of the taxpayer's expenses or a maximum of $500 for individuals. The credit amount is reduced by 5% of adjusted gross income exceeding specified thresholds. The tax credit for residential energy costs under the "Home Heating Oil Assistance Act of 2008" is based on a percentage of the taxpayer's expenses or a maximum of $500 for individuals. The credit amount is reduced by 5% of adjusted gross income exceeding specified thresholds, with definitions and special rules provided for residential energy costs. The tax credit for residential energy costs is based on a percentage of the taxpayer's expenses or a maximum of $500 for individuals. The credit is reduced by 5% of adjusted gross income exceeding specified thresholds. The term 'heating season' is defined as October to March, and the credit applies to qualified fuel used as the primary fuel for heating the taxpayer's principal residence. The tax credit for residential energy costs applies to qualified fuel such as propane, heating oil, kerosene, wood, and wood pellets. Special rules apply for individuals on level payment plans and homeowners associations. The tax credit for residential energy costs applies to qualified fuel types like propane, heating oil, and wood. Stockholders in cooperative housing corporations can allocate the credit among individuals paying for energy costs. The credit is treated as a refundable credit and is subject to inflation adjustments. In 2009, dollar amounts in tax subsections (a)(2) and (b)(2) will be increased based on fuel price inflation and cost-of-living adjustments. In 2009, the fuel price inflation adjustment is based on the CPI fuel component for October of 2008 compared to October of 2007. The adjustment is used to determine the dollar amount increase in tax subsections (a)(2) and (b)(2), with rounding rules applied if necessary. The section outlines rounding rules for dollar amounts in subsections (b)(2) and (f) based on multiples of $10 and $50. It applies to residential energy costs incurred after the enactment date and before January 1, 2010. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Code is amended by adding a new item. The amendments made by this section provide a refundable credit for residential energy costs, effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
